Package com.cyc.kb

Provides basic interfaces for manipulating CycL-based java objects, both for the purpose of making assertions and for retrieving terms and values via simple queries.

See: Description

    Interface Description
    ArgPosition  
    Assertion
    The top-level interface for assertions in a Cyc KB.
    BinaryPredicate
    The interface for KBPredicates that take exactly two arguments.
    Context
    The interface for KBIndividuals that correspond to CycL microtheories.
    Fact
    The interface for Assertions that relate KBCollections and KBIndividuals to each other and to primitive values such as numbers and strings.

    The interface for KBCollections whose members are all KBIndividuals.

    The interface for Cyc functions.

    The top-level interface for Cyc #$Individuals.

    The top-level interface for representing objects in a Cyc KB.

    The interface for Cyc predicates.
    KBTerm
    The top-level interface for most kinds of KBObjects that are not Sentences.

    The interface for logical connectives of the CycL language, such as #$and and #$or.

Package com.cyc.kb Description

Provides basic interfaces for manipulating CycL-based java objects, both for the purpose of making assertions and for retrieving terms and values via simple queries. To use the KB API, you first need to ensure access to a Cyc server, which is done by calling com.cyc.base.CycAccessManager#setCurrentAccess(com.cyc.base.CycAccess) with a CycAccess pointing to a live Cyc server. Because setCurrentAccess sets a thread-local variable, any threads using the KB API need to call setCurrentAccess before doing anything that might need to access a Cyc server. In practice, this means that any non-UI threads spawned in a KB API application need to call setCurrentAccess before anything else happens in the thread. Because methods accessing a Cyc server may not return instantaneously, developers are strongly advised to avoid using KB API methods inside AWT threads (or any threads on which a UI is critically dependent).

The underlying API throws IOException and UnknownHostExeception to indicate some arbitrary IO issue and Cyc server not being at the specified location respectively. In the KB API both of these exceptions are wrapped inside a KBAPIRuntimeException throughout the API and the cause field is set appropriately.

The main uses of the KB API fall into two broad categories: (a) making terms and assertions, and (b) running queries. In order to get the terms needed for making either assertions or queries, the static factory methods (get and findOrCreate) for the relevant implementation classes in com.cyc.kb.client should be called. These factory methods will retrieve the relevant object from the KB, and can be set to create the object on the Cyc server if it doesn't already exist on the server.

Once the objects exists, get and findOrCreate static factory methods in FactImpl and AssertionImpl can be used to create the actual assertions. The KB API generally allows the creation and retrieval of Cyc KB objects (KBIndividuals, KBCollections, Facts, etc.) from a variety of forms including their string representations, their IDs, and from the objects that will comprise them. (In many cases there are additional deprecated methods that accept objects from the CycObject class hierarchy.) The string-based factory methods in AssertionImpl and its sub-classes are a convenient way to create assertions without needing to first create the KBCollection and KBIndividual objects, but they do require correct syntax, and the terms must already exist on the Cyc server.

The API provides many methods that take Strings as inputs. This leads to most methods having CreateException and KBTypeException. To limit the types of exceptions in method signatures, we wrap them in IllegalArgumentException. This is done only to the methods where to focus is not the creation of a new term.

All factory methods throw some exception under CreateException and KBTypeException. To see the possible exceptions under the above exceptions, see StandardKBObject or the description of subclasses of the exceptions.

In many cases, the KB API includes methods that specify a context and similar methods that don't require a context parameter. Default contexts for asserting and querying can be set on a thread-by-thread basis using KBAPIConfiguration.setDefaultContext(com.cyc.kb.config.DefaultContext).

The current implementation of the KB API stores CycObjects as the core of each KBObject. The CycObject can generally be retrieved from each KBObject via the getCore() method. This is useful for cases where lower-level APIs are necessary (e.g. using methods from the CycAccess class directly).
